unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, India – Leading telecom provider, Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL), announced a significant acceleration in its Fiber-to-the-Home (FTTH) rollout across Tier-II and Tier-III cities. The initiative aims to bridge the digital divide and provide high-speed internet connectivity to underserved areas.
normalised: New Delhi, India – Leading telecom provider, B S N L, announced a significant acceleration in its Fiber-to-the-Home (F T T H) rollout across Tier-two and Tier-three cities. The initiative aims to bridge the digital divide and provide high-speed internet connectivity to underserved areas.

unnormalised: Dr. Rajesh Kumar, BSNL's Chairman, stated that the company is targeting to connect an additional 50,000 homes by the end of Q3 2024. The expansion leverages indigenous technology and is partially funded by the Universal Service Obligation Fund (USOF).
normalised: Doctor Rajesh Kumar, B S N L's Chairman, stated that the company is targeting to connect an additional fifty thousand homes by the end of Q three two thousand and twenty four. The expansion leverages indigenous technology and is partially funded by the Universal Service Obligation Fund (U S O F).

unnormalised: The project includes laying approximately 2,000 km of optical fiber cable and installing advanced network equipment. Consumers can expect speeds up to 100 Mbps, enabling seamless streaming and online education. Preliminary reports suggest an increase in property values in connected areas, with analysts noting a potential rise of Rs. 500-Rs. 1000 per sq ft. in residential zones. The enhanced connectivity will also support the government's "Digital India" campaign, fostering economic growth and empowerment. Further details will be discussed at the upcoming Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) summit in Mumbai.
normalised: The project includes laying approximately two thousand kilometer of optical fiber cable and installing advanced network equipment. Consumers can expect speeds up to one hundred M B P S, enabling seamless streaming and online education. Preliminary reports suggest an increase in property values in connected areas, with analysts noting a potential rise of rupee five hundred to rupee one thousand per square foot in residential zones. The enhanced connectivity will also support the government's "Digital India" campaign, fostering economic growth and empowerment. Further details will be discussed at the upcoming Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (T R A I) summit in Mumbai.
